item.title: ✨ My computer build (updated for 2020) by Antoine Collignon
item.content:encoded:
Hello everyone!
As a few I received quite a lots message about this, here is my hardware for work.
This build is focused on GPU rendering capabilities for concept art.

I tailored this build for this kind of tasks :

  • Build and render complex 3D concepts (environment, characters, etc)
  • Use heavy particles system inside 3Dtools
  • Sketch in 3D / VR
  • Render 3D animations out of my various 3D concept in no-time
  • Use Photoshop with loads of memory and fast disk access, thanks to the SSD M2 Nve



All images are clickable



 GPU 


CPU

MEMORY

MOTHERBOARD

SSD

POWER

PC CASE

CPU COOLER

item.title: Sword design by Antoine Collignon
item.content:encoded:
Yo guys,
I just finished a sword design and had a blast working on it ! I'm kinda getting bored of scifi lately




While working on big projects like KeyArt, Keyframe, basically pictures that require realistic scenery with fog and classic architectural stuff, I'm sometimes getting stuck in the process or even bored because it's very technical and not super organic.




By Organic I mean, something alive like you take your stylus and start to sculpt something with some good music and just enjoying the process, making mistake, etc. Damn this feeling is so rewarding I almost forgot about it. So yeah guys, if you ever feel stuck on something (maybe an art block, or just stuck on a personal piece) just destroy the shit out of it by sculpting & creating really weird shapes, I feel like it unlock something to work more in a freestyle mode than just with the usual technical view

Tools of choice :
- Zbrush
- 3DCoat
- GravitySketch

Cheers!

item.title: VR 2074 by Antoine Collignon
item.description:
Pre-production concept art done for an archived project ( video game / shortfilm ) for Opposed Entertainement.
In this scifi / horror world, people wouldn't move from their weird super-connected VR bed anymore, muscles would be totally atrophied, bodies nourished with wires. Really loved this dark sci-fi story !

Made in 2016

item.title: Painting thoughts / tricks by Antoine Collignon
item.content:encoded:
Lately I'm back into pure portrait painting in my free time and I forgot how fascinating is it to observe your brain trying to figure out shapes. No matter how hard you try to draw a nose, a mouth or just a face with a sequential and logicial point of view, it won't look right. Here is one I've started and I couldn't figure it out because I was trying to actually paint logical things instead of really focusing on shapes :


I'm far for a professional painter but lots of aspiring artists think that there is this art noblety thing, like a wizard-ish painting/drawing skills that is very hard to aquire and only reserved to some kind of elite gifted painters. The more I paint, the more I feel like a scientist or a geek analysing shapes to optimize my brain into seeing things with the right side of the brain.

It's a really fascinating process because once you start to focus only on shapes the painting feels alive, more realistic.
Here is another one but this time painted upside down :




Not only I was able to tackle the painting in 30 minutes but it feels way more alive than my first attempt. There is still lots of mistakes especially color-wise but still. So Here is some of my tricks to tackle a painting like a scientist and start enabling your right side of the brain :

  • Blur your reference until you have just a few patch of shapes/colors
  • Paint upside down
  • Force yourself at focusing on shapes and negative spaces
  • I usually use the eraser more than I actually paint. I make big shapes then erase-them until the shape looks like the reference



If you are interested in this subject, I also really recommend the amazing documentary Tim's Vermeer



Hope you can find some of theses informations usefull !
Cheers!

Antoine

item.title: Houdini VDB randomness by Antoine Collignon
item.content:encoded:
Hello guys!
While working with National Geographic on a space project, I had a chance to learn Houdini to help me create nebula and some other secret stuff and what not. This software is kinda hard to get into, especially for someone like me who is used to his Maxon ez 4D environement.
I feel like it's almost as hard as when I started to learn zBrush. 

Here is a little glympse of randomness experiment (made with Houdini, Octane & xParticles)


I'm starting to really dig the FX part of this industry, there is so much to learn in that zone that can help us solve problems :-)

Have a great Friday bros!

item.title: Soul-linked sisters by Antoine Collignon
item.description:
Hello! Here is a piece I created under the (amazing!) Wojtek Fus Mentorship ! He taught me how to approach and push a professional / personal piece with a structured pipeline.

We first worked on a simple logline, to find the right idea/story. Then we started to gather references to make the visual ideas more clear and and get inspired (colors mood, camera angle, poses, visuals shapes). After that, I created all of the assets for the project. I think I gained a lot confidence in approaching a brief, it's so much more easy to makes changes in the final shot.

During the whole production time he was there to review and teach me juicy tricks, this guy is a beast ! So yeah, I'm really happy to have been under his mentorship because I never had any art class before and he really helped me getting the right pipeline for personal and professional projects, thanks Wojtek !

---

www.antoinecollignon.com
contact@antoinecollignon.com
www.fb.com/Collignon.Antoine
item.content:encoded:
Hello! Here is a piece I created under the (amazing!) Wojtek Fus Mentorship ! He taught me how to approach and push a professional / personal piece with a structured pipeline.

We first worked on a simple logline, to find the right idea/story. Then we started to gather references to make the visual ideas more clear and and get inspired (colors mood, camera angle, poses, visuals shapes). After that, I created all of the assets for the project. I think I gained a lot confidence in approaching a brief, it's so much more easy to makes changes in the final shot.

During the whole production time he was there to review and teach me juicy tricks, this guy is a beast ! So yeah, I'm really happy to have been under his mentorship because I never had any art class before and he really helped me getting the right pipeline for personal and professional projects, thanks Wojtek !
